projects.title: Black Hole Dynamics in Stellar Clusters
projects.description:
I am working with Dr. Abbas Askar on a project titled, Black Hole Dynamics in Stellar Clusters. We focus on how the presence of an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) or a subsystem of stellar-mass black holes (BHS) shapes the dynamical evolution of a stellar cluster and its observable properties. We are using stellar cluster models simulated with the MOCCA code to examine how the distribution of observable stellar populations exotica evolves in clusters in the presence or absence of an IMBH or a BHS. My work involves analysing snapshots from hundreds of simulated globular cluster models to find observable properties that can diagnose the dynamical state of the cluster and determine whether it contains a central IMBH or a BHS.
The project has identified apparent differences in segregation between clusters harbouring a BHS or an IMBH by correlating cumulative radial distributions of objects to the cluster's dynamical state. We show clear separations in binary populations depending on the central properties of the cluster and use developed scripts to analyse the formation of observed globular clusters.
I have developed automated scripts to analyse data from over 250 stellar clusters, and this has provided me with valuable assets in handling large data sets, visualising, and correlating observational transients to simulated outcomes. During this project, I have gained knowledge and experience with stellar dynamics, stellar/binary evolution, high energy astrophysics and observations of star clusters. Next semester, we plan on submitting a paper based on the results of my thesis.

projects.title: Disease spreading
projects.description: A simulation describing how Hepatitis B spreads globally considering parameters such as vaccination, population, contact rates and travel opportunities. The aim of the project was to write a script with variable parameters to simulate a realistic approach of disease spreading. The models include the SIS- and SIR model, as analytical comparisons of the subject.

profile_positions.description: I am working with Dr. A. De Almeida Vidotto on investigating stellar winds and coronal mass ejections with numerical simulations. We model stellar winds and CMEs by employing 3D MHD models of the injection and propagation of a CME through the background stellar wind. By comparing the simulation results with observations, the objective is to constrain the most realistic stellar CME scenario, allowing us to assess the impact of episodic mass ejections on the quiescent wind conditions, the duration of these impacts, and their potential effects on close-by exoplanets.

profile_positions.description:
I completed my Master's degree at Lund Observatory in the department of Astronomy and Theoretical Physics. The University publication is open access and accessible through: 
https://lup.lub.lu.se/student-papers/search/publication/9095211

Details:
I investigated how the presence of an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) or a subsystem of stellar-mass black holes (BHS) shapes the dynamical evolution of a stellar cluster and its observable properties. We used stellar cluster models simulated with the MOCCA code to examine how the distribution of observable stellar populations exotica evolves in clusters in the presence or absence of an IMBH or a BHS. My work involved analysing snapshots from hundreds of simulated globular cluster models to find observable properties that can diagnose the dynamical state of the cluster and determine whether it contains a central IMBH or a BHS.

The project has identified apparent differences in segregation between clusters harbouring a BHS or an IMBH by correlating cumulative radial distributions of objects to the cluster's dynamical state. We show clear separations in binary populations depending on the central properties of the cluster and use developed scripts to analyse the formation of observed globular clusters. By correlating the amount of segregation in these clusters to the amount of black holes retained and also their masses, we estimated the numbers of BHs and masses of potential IMBHs in real observed globular clusters in the Milky Way.

profile_positions.description:
I worked as a summer research assistant in cooperation with Dr. Ross Church on main-sequence star collisions at the galactic centre. 

Detailed information: 
By using smoothed particle hydrodynamics, I simulated 576 low mass main-sequence star collisions in the galactic centre and extended simulation outcomes from Freitag and Benz (2005) concerning the fractional mass-loss, the number of retained objects and final star masses by implementing a Delaunay interpolation. Post-collision characteristics of remnants were investigated, allowing us to evolve these within stellar evolution codes.

We concluded the assumption of inelastic collisions to be inadequate for NSC stellar collisions. The resulting outcomes help us acknowledge the importance of stellar collisions on post stellar and cluster evolution in the galactic centre. Acquired results will be contained in an upcoming paper in cooperation with Dr. Ross Church.

profile_positions.description:
I obtained a bachelor degree in physics at Lund University 2020 with the highest possible grade. Link to LU publication: http://lup.lub.lu.se/student-papers/record/9018128

Details:
I used numerical methods to simulate the spread of highly developed civilisations in the solar neighbourhood, applying epicycle dynamics and probability distributions for planetary evolution. The project aimed to track the colonisation of suitable planets by one or several space-travelling civilisations, with probabilities for close encountering systems to develop intelligent life.
I establish correlations between civilisation development time and the number of planets colonised.

As a result, I found that the spread of hypothetical civilisations strongly correlates with the distance between close encountering systems and the time for systems to develop suitable conditions for life. With a rapid development of life for surrounding planets, I show that the first developed civilisation can colonise planets faster than new civilisations develop.
